questions.question: In FSK, binary 1 and 0 are represented by:
questions.explanation: In Frequency Shift Keying (FSK), binary 1 and 0 are represented by two different frequencies. This allows the receiver to distinguish between the bits based on frequency changes.

questions.question: FSK modulation is primarily used for:
questions.explanation: FSK is commonly used for transmitting digital data over communication channels because it is more robust to noise compared to amplitude-based schemes.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of FSK over ASK?
questions.explanation: FSK has better noise immunity than Amplitude Shift Keying (ASK) because frequency variations are less affected by noise than amplitude changes.
